Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Organic Nitrogen Cycling in Northern Hardwood - Conifer Forests
Award.AbstractNarration:
The current conceptual model for the nitrogen (N) cycle of northeastern US forests stresses the importance of inorganic N forms (i.e., ammonium and nitrate) for tree growth and forest productivity. However, organic forms of N are also be taken up by plants. The overall objective of this proposal is to quantify the importance of organic N as a nutrient source in temperate forest ecosystems of the northeastern U.S. To achieve this objective, the factors that affect the production and turnover of organic N in the soil will be studied, focusing specifically on amino acids and amino sugars. The balance between the production and turnover of organic N will be assessed to determine the types and forms of N taken up by dominant tree species. These objectives will be met by establishing plants in single-species stands on two types of soil parent materials in western Connecticut and Massachusetts. Field and laboratory studies will be used to measure the pools, fluxes and uptake of organic N in the soil.
The availability of N in the soil limits the productivity of forest ecosystems and their capacity to sequester rising concentrations of carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas. By understanding the factors that affect the form and the quantity of N taken up by forest trees, this proposal will shed light on the processes regulating the availability of a key growth limiting soil resource and the degree to which forest ecosystems can be relied upon to absorb CO2 from the earth's atmosphere.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Research: Organic Nitrogen Cycling in Northern Hardwood - Conifer Forests

Our collaborator on this project was Dr. Adrien Finzi of Boston University. This project improved our knowledge of how forests function in several areas and also developed several new approaches that will be useful to other scientists investigating how forests function. One important advance was to show a link between function of different species of symbiotic fungi (called ectomycorrhizal fungi) and how sensitive those species were to nitrogen deposition and pollution. If trees lose some species of their associated fungi, this could significantly affect tree nutrient supply and ultimately damage tree health. We also improved the usefulness of a widely used tool in ecosystem science, isotopic measurements. We developed an approach to interpreting these measurements in fungal carbon and nitrogen that accounted for differences in the biochemical makeup of the fungi. This approach therefore allows better comparisons across sites, species, and studies. In a second aspect, we did a comprehensive literature review and concluded that climate cannot be used to infer trace gas fluxes of nitrous oxide, an important greenhouse gas. We therefore conclude that interactions between plants, symbiotic fungi, and climate may be a key link determining trace gas flux rates.

 Although we generally think of ammonium and nitrate as the forms of nitrogen used by trees, it is increasingly clear that organic forms of nitrogen (such as amino acids) are also very important nitrogen sources. In this project, we developed develop two new ways to assess organic nitrogen use in ectomycorrhizal fungi and in trees. One approach used the radiocarbon (carbon-14) injected into the atmosphere during thermonuclear testing in the 1950s and 1960s and the other used bacteria artificially labeled with stable (non-radioactive) isotopes as a substrate for decomposition and plant nitrogen supply. Both these methods improved the assessment of a major unknown in plant nutrient supply. The first method also provides new opportunities to use herbarium specimens to examine ecosystem processes in the past.

In this project, we trained many undergraduate students in laboratory techniques and scientific approaches and mentored one undergraduate for her senior thesis. Students were encouraged to develop individual projects that could be presented to their peers and the wider university community in formal settings, with one of those students subsequently co-authoring a scientific paper. Two PhD students on the project received a significant portion of their training while working on this project, which included developing independent research projects and managing and mentoring undergraduate students working directly for them. Our public outreach has focused on fungal forays (mushroom walks) to reach children and adults in which the participants find mushrooms and we then discuss their roles in supplying nutrients for trees, in breaking down wood and litter to release nutrients, in serving as food for other animals, and in cooking (how do you determine if a mushroom is edible – very carefully!).
